sentences: Collecting high profile users private information is the trend in recent times. We came across a twitter post that described one such incident involving VajraSpy, an Android RAT that uses a designated Google Cloud Storage to store the data stolen from the user. VajraSpy is used by APT-Q-43 (#VajraEleph) group targeting Pakistani military personnel. VajraSpy appeared new and it disguises itself as a chat app called Crazy Talk.

One of the common ways to curtail the activity of a Spyware or any malware includes the detection of C2 or the URL which the malware communicates to. Affirming the maliciousness of such applications that communicates and copies the users data to a legitimate hosting service or a server using the standard protocols and frameworks, becomes a knotty procedure. In recent times, Android malwares poisoning of available standard frameworks and globally accepted services for malicious purposes is increasing. Users of K7 Mobile Security are protected against VajraSpy.
Lets get into the details of how this VajraSpy works.

Collecting high profile users private information is the trend in recent times. We came across a twitter post that described one such incident involving VajraSpy, an Android RAT that uses a designated Google Cloud Storage to store the data stolen from the user. VajraSpy is used by APT-Q-43 (#VajraEleph) group targeting Pakistani military personnel. VajraSpy appeared new and it disguises itself as a chat app called Crazy Talk.

We came across a twitter post that described one such incident involving VajraSpy, an Android RAT that uses a designated Google Cloud Storage to store the data stolen from the user. VajraSpy is used by APT-Q-43 (#VajraEleph) group targeting Pakistani military personnel. VajraSpy appeared new and it disguises itself as a chat app called Crazy Talk.
This malware uses Firebase cloud Storage to store the data collected from a compromised device.

Collecting high profile users private information is the trend in recent times. We came across a twitter post that described one such incident involving VajraSpy, an Android RAT that uses a designated Google Cloud Storage to store the data stolen from the user. VajraSpy is used by APT-Q-43 (#VajraEleph) group targeting Pakistani military personnel. VajraSpy appeared new and it disguises itself as a chat app called Crazy Talk.
Unzipping the CrazyTalk.apk sample showed that this is a Spy and includes more than one classes.dex as shown in Figure 1 and the other classes.dex files are loaded using Multidex support.
Unzipping the CrazyTalk.apk sample showed that this is a Spy and includes more than one classes.dex as shown in Figure 1 and the other classes.dex files are loaded using Multidex support.
Figure 1: Spy with many classes.dex

Analysis starts with the MainActivity of classes2.dex, the apps entry point. MainActivitys onCreate() function confirms that the app has Notification Access and Accessibility Service allowed and collects the Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM) token as shown in Figure 2.

In addition to the above contacts.json, this malicious app also collects other user data like SMS messages, call logs, WhatsApp (including business accounts) messages, Signal app messages, device details, apps listed from the victims device as shown in Figure 6.
As shown in Figure 5, putBytes() function uploads the data (in our case here, it is contacts.json) to the Firebase Storage via the StorageReference object.
Figure 9: WAB.json array creation from entrywb table in FeedReaderwb.db
Figure 8: Uploading collected WhatsApp messages metadata to entrywb table in FeedReaderwb.db
Figure 9: WAB.json array creation from entrywb table in FeedReaderwb.db

Analysis starts with the MainActivity of classes2.dex, the apps entry point. MainActivitys onCreate() function confirms that the app has Notification Access and Accessibility Service allowed and collects the Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM) token as shown in Figure 2.

Analysis starts with the MainActivity of classes2.dex, the apps entry point. MainActivitys onCreate() function confirms that the app has Notification Access and Accessibility Service allowed and collects the Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM) token as shown in Figure 2.
This app CrazyTalk impersonates a chat app and requests for the permissions as shown in Figure 3.
This malware initializes the Firebase Storage as shown in Figure 4.
After the FirebaseStorage initialization, this app collects the victims personal information by initiating an instance of the StorageReference object as shown in Figure 5.
After the FirebaseStorage initialization, this app collects the victims personal information by initiating an instance of the StorageReference object as shown in Figure 5.
As shown in Figure 5, putBytes() function uploads the data (in our case here, it is contacts.json) to the Firebase Storage via the StorageReference object.
Figure 5: StorageReference initialization to upload collected victims information
After the FirebaseStorage initialization, this app collects the victims personal information by initiating an instance of the StorageReference object as shown in Figure 5.
As shown in Figure 5, putBytes() function uploads the data (in our case here, it is contacts.json) to the Firebase Storage via the StorageReference object.

In addition to the above contacts.json, this malicious app also collects other user data like SMS messages, call logs, WhatsApp (including business accounts) messages, Signal app messages, device details, apps listed from the victims device as shown in Figure 6.

WhatsApp or WhatsAppBusiness or Signal messages are collected from a victims device and stored in a designated table in the SQLite DB which is then uploaded to the designated Firebase Cloud Storage as shown in Figures 7, 8 and 9.
Figure 6: Collecting WhatsApp Business account and Signal app messages in JSON format
Figure 7: Collecting WhatsAppBusiness messages

WhatsApp or WhatsAppBusiness or Signal messages are collected from a victims device and stored in a designated table in the SQLite DB which is then uploaded to the designated Firebase Cloud Storage as shown in Figures 7, 8 and 9.
